metadata.description: Few-shot examples for Boolean expression discovery

expressions.explanation: The output matches the value of variable x. When x=0, output=0. This is a simple identity function where the result is directly determined by the value of x.
The output matches the value of variable y. When y=0, output=0. This is a simple identity function where the result is directly determined by the value of y.
The output is 1 only when both x and y are 1. In this case, both x and y are 0, so the output is 0. This represents a logical conjunction where both inputs must be true for the output to be true.
This expression is always false regardless of the input values because x AND NOT x is a contradiction. When x=0, NOT x=1, so 0 AND 1 = 0.
This expression is always false regardless of the input values because y AND NOT y is a contradiction. When y=0, NOT y=1, so 0 AND 1 = 0.
The output matches the value of variable y. When y=1, output=1. This is a simple identity function where the result is directly determined by the value of y.
The output is the negation of x. When x=0, NOT x=1, which matches the output. This represents a logical negation where the output is true when x is false.
The output is 1 when either x or y (or both) are 1. In this case, x=0 and y=1, so x OR y = 0 OR 1 = 1. This represents a logical disjunction where the output is true if at least one input is true.
This expression is always true regardless of the input values because y OR NOT y is a tautology. When y=1, NOT y=0, so 1 OR 0 = 1.
This expression is always true regardless of the input values because x OR NOT x is a tautology. When x=0, NOT x=1, so 0 OR 1 = 1.
The output matches the value of variable x. When x=0, output=0; when x=1, output=1. This is a simple identity function where the result is directly determined by the value of x.
The output matches the value of variable y. When y=0, output=0; when y=1, output=1. This is a simple identity function where the result is directly determined by the value of y.
The output is 1 only when both x and y are 1. When x=0 and y=0, output=0; when x=1 and y=1, output=1. This represents a logical conjunction where both inputs must be true for the output to be true.

The output is 1 when either x or y (or both) are 1. When x=0 and y=0, output=0; when x=1 and y=1, output=1. This represents a logical disjunction where the output is true if at least one input is true.

This expression simplifies to always true because x AND NOT x is always false, and NOT false is true. However, it matches the observations: when x=0, output=0 (this doesn't match, so this is not a valid expression for this observation set).

The output is 1 when either x or y (or both) are 1. This matches all observations: when x=0,y=0: 0 OR 0 = 0; when x=0,y=1: 0 OR 1 = 1; when x=1,y=0: 1 OR 0 = 1. This represents a logical disjunction where the output is true if at least one input is true.
The output is 0 only when both x and y are 1. This matches all observations: when x=0,y=0: NOT(0 AND 0) = NOT(0) = 1 (doesn't match, so this is not valid).
This is a more complex expression. When x=0,y=0: 0 OR NOT(0 AND 0) = 0 OR NOT(0) = 0 OR 1 = 1 (doesn't match first observation).
The output is 1 only when both x and y are 1. When x=0,y=1: 0 AND 1 = 0; when x=1,y=0: 1 AND 0 = 0. This matches both observations and represents a logical conjunction.

The output is 1 only when both x and y are 0. When x=0,y=1: NOT(0 OR 1) = NOT(1) = 0; when x=1,y=0: NOT(1 OR 0) = NOT(1) = 0. This matches both observations and represents the negation of a disjunction (NOR).
This expression is always false regardless of the input values because x AND NOT x is a contradiction. When x=0: 0 AND 1 = 0; when x=1: 1 AND 0 = 0. This matches both observations.
This expression is always false regardless of the input values because y AND NOT y is a contradiction. When y=1: 1 AND 0 = 0; when y=0: 0 AND 1 = 0. This matches both observations.
The output is the negation of y. When y=0, NOT y=1; when y=1, NOT y=0. This matches both observations and represents a logical negation of variable y.

The output is 1 only when both x and y are 0. When x=0,y=0: NOT(0 OR 0) = NOT(0) = 1; when x=0,y=1: NOT(0 OR 1) = NOT(1) = 0. This matches both observations and represents the negation of a disjunction (NOR).

The output is 1 only when both x and y are 0. When x=0,y=0: NOT 0 AND NOT 0 = 1 AND 1 = 1; when x=0,y=1: NOT 0 AND NOT 1 = 1 AND 0 = 0. This matches both observations and represents a logical conjunction of the negations of both variables.

The output is 1 when either x is 1 or y is 0 (or both). When x=0,y=0: 0 OR NOT 0 = 0 OR 1 = 1; when x=0,y=1: 0 OR NOT 1 = 0 OR 0 = 0. This matches both observations and represents a logical disjunction.
This is a more complex expression. When x=0,y=0: NOT 0 OR (0 AND 0) = 1 OR 0 = 1; when x=0,y=1: NOT 1 OR (0 AND 1) = 0 OR 0 = 0. This matches both observations.
The output matches the value of variable y. When y=1, output=1; when y=0, output=0. This is a simple identity function where the result is directly determined by the value of y.
The output is 1 only when x is 0 and y is 1. When x=0,y=1: NOT 0 AND 1 = 1 AND 1 = 1; when x=1,y=0: NOT 1 AND 0 = 0 AND 0 = 0. This matches both observations and represents a logical conjunction.
The output is 1 when y is 1 and either x or y is 1. When x=0,y=1: 1 AND (0 OR 1) = 1 AND 1 = 1; when x=1,y=0: 0 AND (1 OR 0) = 0 AND 1 = 0. This matches both observations.
This is a more complex expression. When x=0,y=1: NOT 0 OR (0 AND 1) = 1 OR 0 = 1; when x=1,y=0: NOT 1 OR (1 AND 0) = 0 OR 0 = 0. This matches both observations.
This expression uses the fact that x AND NOT x is always 0. When x=0,y=1: 1 OR (0 AND 1) = 1 OR 0 = 1; when x=1,y=0: 0 OR (1 AND 0) = 0 OR 0 = 0. This matches both observations.

The output is 1 only when x is 0 and y is 1. This matches all observations: when x=0,y=0: NOT 0 AND 0 = 1 AND 0 = 0; when x=0,y=1: NOT 0 AND 1 = 1 AND 1 = 1; when x=1,y=0: NOT 1 AND 0 = 0 AND 0 = 0. This represents a logical conjunction of the negation of x with y.

This expression is 1 when y is 1 and not both x and y are 1. When x=0,y=0: 0 AND NOT(0 AND 0) = 0 AND NOT(0) = 0 AND 1 = 0; when x=0,y=1: 1 AND NOT(0 AND 1) = 1 AND NOT(0) = 1 AND 1 = 1; when x=1,y=0: 0 AND NOT(1 AND 0) = 0 AND NOT(0) = 0 AND 1 = 0. This matches all observations.

This expression uses the fact that x OR NOT x is always 1. When x=0,y=0: 0 AND (0 OR 1) = 0 AND 1 = 0; when x=0,y=1: 1 AND (0 OR 1) = 1 AND 1 = 1; when x=1,y=0: 0 AND (1 OR 0) = 0 AND 1 = 0. This matches all observations.

The output matches the value of variable x. When x=0, output=0; when x=1, output=1. This is a simple identity function where the result is directly determined by the value of x. It matches all observations.

The output is 1 when either x or y (or both) are 1. This matches all observations: when x=0,y=0: 0 OR 0 = 0; when x=1,y=0: 1 OR 0 = 1; when x=1,y=1: 1 OR 1 = 1. This represents a logical disjunction where the output is true if at least one input is true.

This expression simplifies to just x, since x AND (x OR y) = x. When x=0,y=0: 0 AND (0 OR 0) = 0 AND 0 = 0; when x=1,y=0: 1 AND (1 OR 0) = 1 AND 1 = 1; when x=1,y=1: 1 AND (1 OR 1) = 1 AND 1 = 1. This matches all observations.

This expression also simplifies to just x, since x OR (x AND y) = x. When x=0,y=0: 0 OR (0 AND 0) = 0 OR 0 = 0; when x=1,y=0: 1 OR (1 AND 0) = 1 OR 0 = 1; when x=1,y=1: 1 OR (1 AND 1) = 1 OR 1 = 1. This matches all observations.

expressions.expression: NOT (x AND y) AND (x OR y)
expressions.explanation: This expression is 1 when at least one variable is 1 but not both are 1. When x=0,y=0: NOT(0 AND 0) AND (0 OR 0) = NOT(0) AND 0 = 1 AND 0 = 0; when x=0,y=1: NOT(0 AND 1) AND (0 OR 1) = NOT(0) AND 1 = 1 AND 1 = 1; when x=1,y=0: NOT(1 AND 0) AND (1 OR 0) = NOT(0) AND 1 = 1 AND 1 = 1; when x=1,y=1: NOT(1 AND 1) AND (1 OR 1) = NOT(1) AND 1 = 0 AND 1 = 0. This matches all observations.

expressions.expression: x AND NOT y OR NOT x AND y
expressions.explanation: This expression represents XOR (exclusive or) using basic operators. When x=0,y=0: 0 AND NOT 0 OR NOT 0 AND 0 = 0 AND 1 OR 1 AND 0 = 0 OR 0 = 0; when x=0,y=1: 0 AND NOT 1 OR NOT 0 AND 1 = 0 AND 0 OR 1 AND 1 = 0 OR 1 = 1; when x=1,y=0: 1 AND NOT 0 OR NOT 1 AND 0 = 1 AND 1 OR 0 AND 0 = 1 OR 0 = 1; when x=1,y=1: 1 AND NOT 1 OR NOT 1 AND 1 = 1 AND 0 OR 0 AND 1 = 0 OR 0 = 0. This matches all observations.
